com.nyteshade
Enum EmbedWeb

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Enum<EmbedWeb>
      com.nyteshade.EmbedWeb
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<EmbedWeb>
public enum EmbedWeb
extends Enum<EmbedWeb>

EmbedWeb is a convenience class that wraps the HttpServer Sun, now Oracle, bundles with JDK6+. This provides an incredibly easy way to implement a HTTP listener in any Java based application, be it a desktop app or an app server like Tomcat. Combined with a JSON encoder/decoder it can be a powerful solution to providing an API for your application. Creating an HttpServer on port 7070 that listens to the root (/) path is as simple as: 


   EmbedWeb.WEB.addHandler(7070, "/", new HttpHandler() {
     public void handle(HttpExchange httpExchange) throws IOException {
       Map<String, Object> params = EmbedWeb.getParameters(httpExchange);
       StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder();

       if (params.containsKey("name")) {
         buffer.append("Hello " + params.get("name") + "");
       } else {
         buffer.append("Whats up punk?!");
       }

       EmbedWeb.respondWith(httpExchange, 200, buffer, "text/html");
     }
   });

   EmbedWeb.WEB.startServer(7070);

Version:
12-FEB-2013
Author:
Brielle Harrison

          A nice filter which takes the dirty work out of obtaining parameters in a given HttpHandler.

serverOn

protected HttpServer serverOn(int port,
                              boolean https)
Called on WEB; if no server exists at the port supplied, one will be created. Only in the case of an IOException will a null server be returned.

Parameters:
port - an integer detailing which port on this server the web listener should act on.
Returns:
an instance of HttpServer or null if an IOException is thrown.

addHandler

public HttpContext addHandler(int port,
                              String path,
                              HttpHandler handler)
Used to add a new endpoint on a server at the specified port. If a server doesn't exist at that port, one will be created. The handler and contexts created will automatically have the EmbedWeb.ParameterFilter applied.

Parameters:
port - the numerical port on which the server to have a new endpoint added should run on
path - a path such as "/home" or "/login" or whatever else you wish to use to serve data.
handler - an instance of HttpHandler which is used to handle what happens when the endpoint is accessed.
Returns:
an instance of HttpContext which has already had the EmbedWeb.ParameterFilter and the supplied handler applied to it.

addHandler

public HttpContext addHandler(int port,
                              String path,
                              HttpHandler handler,
                              boolean https)
Used to add a new endpoint on a server at the specified port. If a server doesn't exist at that port, one will be created. The handler and contexts created will automatically have the EmbedWeb.ParameterFilter applied.

Parameters:
port - the numerical port on which the server to have a new endpoint added should run on
path - a path such as "/home" or "/login" or whatever else you wish to use to serve data.
handler - an instance of HttpHandler which is used to handle what happens when the endpoint is accessed.
https - true if the server is secure; false otherwise
Returns:
an instance of HttpContext which has already had the EmbedWeb.ParameterFilter and the supplied handler applied to it.

getContext

public HttpContext getContext(int port,
                              String path)
Get the context running on a server on port port with the supplied path or null if there is none or there is no server running on that port.

Parameters:
port - the numerical port on which the server to have a new endpoint added should run on
path - a path such as "/home" or "/login" or whatever else you wish to use to serve data.
Returns:
the instance of HttpContext for that path on that port

setContext

public boolean setContext(int port,
                          String path,
                          HttpContext context)
Overrides the context at a given port and path. If there is no server running at the supplied port then false is returned. Otherwise the given context is set on the server at the supplied port and true is returned.

Parameters:
port - the numerical port on which the server to have a new endpoint added should run on
path - a path such as "/home" or "/login" or whatever else you wish to use to serve data.
context - an instance of HttpContext to set on the server
Returns:
true if setting was successful; false otherwise

respondWith

public static void respondWith(HttpExchange exchange,
                               int responseCode,
                               StringBuilder buffer)
                        throws IOException
Another helper method, respondWith takes all the annoying content length calculation, response header sending and stream closing as long as the user can provide the desired responseCode and a StringBuilder with all the content to write out to the response.

Parameters:
exchange - an instance of HttpExchange that pertains to the current handler.
responseCode - a WEB response code (i.e. 200, 304, 500, etc...)
buffer - a StringBuilder with the output content to respond with.
Throws:
IOException - a IOException may possibly be thrown by the execution of this method.

respondWith

public static void respondWith(HttpExchange exchange,
                               int responseCode,
                               StringBuilder buffer,
                               String mimeType)
                        throws IOException
Identical to respondWith(com.sun.net.httpserver.HttpExchange, int, StringBuilder) with the exception that you may also specify the desired mime type of the response. Examples are "text/html", "text/plain", "text/javascript" or the more desired "application/javascript", etc...

Parameters:
exchange - an instance of HttpExchange that pertains to the current handler.
responseCode - a WEB response code (i.e. 200, 304, 500, etc...)
buffer - a StringBuilder with the output content to respond with.
mimeType - a WEB mime-type see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIME_type for more information.
Throws:
IOException - a IOException may possibly be thrown by the execution of this method.

public void startServer(int port)
Starts the server on the specified port

Parameters:
port - the port denoting which server to start. Nothing happens if there is no server at the port specified.

getParameters

public static Map<String,Object> getParameters(HttpExchange exchange)
Rather than the long type cast and needing to know the name of the attribute that the parameters for the request are stored under, this static method will perform that work for you if you only supply the HttpExchange object in question.

Parameters:
exchange - an instance of HttpExchange that is relevant to the request in question
Returns:
a Map of String, Object pairs denoting the parameters for the request.
